text: Bottle (Shared by BVery- Thanks!); pours cloudy light amber with a white head; aroma of yeast funk with some light spice and some citrus and floral hints; taste is yeasty with citrus, a little pepper, and traces of wood; dry finish with a hint of the pinot
Bomber shared by Bvery, thanks? Aroma is fine, tart apples. Taste is strange, like dandelion stems (thanks for that explanation Brian). Not sure what happened here.

Bottle share by Brian, thanks! Pours a clear light yellow with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of herbal and floral notes with some tonic and a bit of funky grains. Flavor has a funky note with some herbal grains, flora and a light fruit note supporting.
Bottle shared by Brian, thanks! Golden yellow pour with a white head. Honey apple nose with a dash of vegetation.
Bomber from a shop in Juneau. Yellow pour with a white head. Dandelions, rose petals, tannins from the wine barrel. Wanted to like this more.
Amber, small white head. Herbal, flowery aroma. Flavor is floral, sweet, herbal. Carbonation is too low.

Dark amber pour with perhaps some reddish tint. Cloudy with a quick, bubbly white foam. Rich, vinegary nose with some earthy yeast (brett) notes around the edges. Earthy, vinous flavors in the middle pick up some (rather muted) malt. The spices, green apple notes and citrus bitterness gives the flavors depth. The flavor is tart, but not as tart as the nose. Medium to light body with restrained fizz. The finish is not as dry as the nose might suggest. The pinot noir barrels give it an earthy depth that takes it to the (relatively) less dry end of the saison spectrum. The 8% ABV makes it more of a super saison and matches the complexity of the flavors. (Batch 24 December 2015)

Purchased in Montpelier, Vermont. Pours a cleaner golden colour with beautiful carbonation. Gets hazier at every pour. White creamy head, very good retention and some nice lacing. Earthy funky aromas from the Bretts. The yeast shows up with time, adding some balance of sweetness. Hints of roses and cherries. The taste is surprisingly bitter. Was not excepting this for a Saison, but here it is. Some of the orange notes lingers. Some much going on, hard to get the oak barrels used in this one. The nose gets a little more bitter as the beer gets completely cloudy. Quite a unique Saison which is nice to share and sip.

750 ml corked and caged bottle. Sat for awhile in a cellar. The aroma has mild perfume, mild Brett, rose pedals. 
Flavor shows me a mild fruit note upfront before turning to Rose pedals and a mild funky yeast. Mild oak. As I drink it the tartness and spice hints. The beer shows a bone dry texture. Overall, pretty damn nice.
Bottle, nice aromas and full body beer, with hints of wood adds more complex flavors to this extraordinary beer. light over carbonated.

Love Buzz is the kind of funky beauty IÂ’ve come to expect from Anchorage. It pours light amber - the subtle reddish tint evidently comes from the rose petals used in this brew. Floral, woodsy, vinous, and yeasty aromas. Flavor is deeply complex with bready and earthy yeast, rose, wine tannins, spices, a slight cheesiness, and zesty fruit. Moderately lively feel and quite a bit of bitterness (redolent of fruit pith) for a Saison. The musty elements will be difficult for the uninitiated, but if you believe that rot can be gorgeous, this will exceed your expectations.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2016 Corked bottle. Heavy fruit aroma - peach and strawberry. Opaque amber appearance, mild carbonation. Can definitely taste the pinot initially, though also has heavy cheesy funk. Alcoholic finish. Definitely a sipper...but very unique.

bomber, WallyÂ’s @ $12.99. Pours a hazy, soft gold with a medium coarse white head. Dusty aromas of white pepper, coriander, hint of Brett, coconut. Flavor has peppery saison yeast, mild tang of mandarin orange, and a background woodsy vinous element. Body is medium, fuller than most Saisons, probably due to Alcohol and barrel aging. A complex and tasty drink, though IÂ’m less convinced that the final product is greater than the individual parts that went into this.

Corked bottle from Kenny Road Market: hazy amber, white-ish head. aroma of musty, straw, floral, tart, lemon - very nice. tastes are orange, lemon, bretty, barnyard, yeasty, light spice, grapefruit acidic juicy, only light wood. thin juicy palate. kinda perfect.

Bottle shared with Gus. Aroma is pinot noir, clove, spices, tart, really nice. Appearance is reddish golden, hazy, off white head. Taste is pinot noir, tart, dry, barnyard, spices, good. Mouthfeel is medium body, light crisp carbonation, pinot noir aftertaste. Overall, IÂ’m enjoying this very much.

Bottle from Gourmet Haus Staudt in Redwood City, CA ($18 take-away). Pours a picturesque light golden amber. Aroma is mild funk, light orange blossoms, fermented orange peels, citra hops. Palate is creamy smooth yet crisp. Taste is a complex stew of bright orange, rotten orange, floral orange, medicinal / vitamins, spicy pepper, hops... so much going on that this shouldnÂ’t be good but it works. A rotten potpourri of a beer that is quite glorious.

750ml bottle. Clear orange with a foamy white head. Flavors are biscuity cereals, caramel, citrus, melon, oak, funk and pepper with vinous, floral and medicinal notes. Medium body, moderate to good carbonation, oily texture.

Finally bucked up to buy this bottle. Pours a hazy golden orangish glow, with a fluffy white head. Aroma of chardonnay, orange zest, barnyard funk and light malts. Taste is orange marmalade, funky brett yeast, mouth puckering grapefruit. Dry finish. Zero detection of alcohol. Damn fine beer. Would recommend to others for sure.

Bottled. Pours hazy golden with an average white head. Aroma of hoppy citrus notes, funk, yeast, vanilla, wood, grapes and spices. Slightly sweet flavor that ends up being dry and slightly bitter. Medium bodied, oily texture and average to lively carbonation. An excellent Saison.ðŸŒŸðŸŒŸðŸŒŸðŸŒŸ

Bottle (Dec 2015 date). Pours golden with an off-white fluffy head. Minimal bubbles stick to the glass as I drink it. Smells of berries, oak, spices, sweet malts, some alcohol. Medium sweet with a light bitterness underneath. Tastes of soft Brett, spices, sweet malts, some fruit. Medium+ bodied. Flavors last well into the finish.

(Bottle) Cloudy orange body with a large, dissipating eggshell head. Wonderful aroma of wheat, red wine, fruit, yeast, spice, some wood, and a hint of brett sourness. Medium body, full carbonation, sticky mouthfeel. Flavor of red wine, brettanomyces, grapes, rose, pepper, medium hops. The combination of elements combine surprisingly well in the aroma but not as successfully in the flavor.
Funky oaky aroma. Pours cloudy orange with a white head. Nice flavor with a sour finish.
Cellar aged bomber. Very nice funk and saison balance with a slightly sour finish and very smooth!

UPDATED: APR 9, 2017 Bottle: Cloudy orange with a small head and no lace. Very funky aroma and palate. Sour for a saison, more of a lactic than brett profile. 
Over ripe orange or mandarine rind with spice. Good length and mouthfeel. 
Very refreshing

750 ml bottle into tulip glass; Batch #4, bottled in 12/2015. Pours lightly hazy golden orange color with a 2 finger fairly dense and fluffy white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of big tart lemon, lime, grapefruit, orange peel, citrus rind, peppercorn, apricot, pineapple, melon, red wine, hay, straw, leather, musty funk, herbal, floral, toasted oak, bread, light caramel/vanilla, and yeast/oak earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of fruity/funky/acidic yeast, spices, wine barrel, and light-moderate bready malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big tart lemon, lime, grapefruit, orange peel, citrus rind, peppercorn, apricot, pineapple, melon, red wine, hay, straw, leather, musty funk, herbal, floral, toasted oak, bread, light caramel/vanilla, and yeast/oak earthiness. Large amount of peppery yeast/tannic oak spiciness and moderate tartness on the finish; with lingering notes of tart lemon, lime, grapefruit, orange peel, citrus rind, peppercorn, apricot, pineapple, melon, red wine, hay, straw, leather, musty funk, herbal, floral, toasted oak, and yeast/oak earthiness on the finish for a while. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/funky/acidic yeast, spices, wine barrel, and light-moderate bready malt flavors; with a great malt/tart/spiciness balance and zero astringent flavors after the finish. Good dryness from tart/spiciness as well. Medium-high carbonation and medium body; with a very smooth, crisp, acidic/tannic/sticky, and lightly creamy/grainy balanced mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent Brett saison. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/funky/acidic yeast, spices, wine barrel, and light-moderate bready malt flavors; very smooth, crisp, and easy to drink for the ABV. A very enjoyable offering.

750ml corked and caged bottle. Hazy, Cloudy yellow pour, with a big white head. Aroma is is spicy, herbal, light rose water, some malted wheat, light funk, light tropical fruit and some fresh cut grass. Nice mouth feel, normal carb. Finish is woody, light vinous notes, earthy and slightly funky. Some light lactic funk, soft oak, and more light fruit and tartness with some good herbal, hoppy, slightly peppery end.

Sample at the "Post Beer Week Bottle Share" on 06/06/16. The beer is a hazy golden color with a medium white head that burns away steadily to a film. Stringy lacing. Aroma of funky yeast, citrus and malt. Medium body with flavors of vinous oak, brett yeast, citrus and malt. The finish is funky and fruity with a bretty aftertaste. Good beer all around.

Bottle to tulip
Consummation: Brettafuckingbrett, grapes, C-Hops, pepper and citrus. Unique...at least for me and my measly 1500 ratings.
Adjunct: Aroma of flowers, mandarin, grapefruit, and grapes; cloudy reddish amber with a thin ringed creamy and bright white head
Nice one.
This is a traditional saison thatÂ’s been modified thru use of casting the brew in wine storage. itÂ’sok, but I like Firestone WalkeÂ’so version w/ hops better

750 ml bottle. Fairly clear gold pour, couple fingers of fluffy white head, some lacing. Lots in the aroma, flowery / perfume, citrus, peppery spice, vinous notes as well. For me the taste was dominated by the rose hips / flowers, not my favorite. Some funk / tartness is present as well as a slew of others.

750ml corked bottle pours a pale golden amber color with a finger and a half of white pillowy head that leaves some decent lacing on the glass. Aroma is red wine grapes with some floral notes and hints of yeast and citrus. Taste is a lemony tartness with a citrus and caramel malty sweetness and a dry red wine finish. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, a flavorful brew that suits the style well and adds a twist with the addition of the rose hips.

Bright orange hazy color with small white head and nice lacing. Aroma is huge, great vinous nose, with grapes and fruitiness, a bit sour, and grassy yeast. Strong grapey flavor with deep oak notes. Sweet and tart, and almost bit creamy at the end. Not as yeasty of a flavor as I was expecting but very good overall.

Bottle from Beer Store. Thin-medium bodied saison. Funk, white wine, wheat, floral, spice and citrus notes. Great balance. You would hardly know the alcohol content of this by drinking though the white wine is hinting. Love the flavors. Funky up citrus with floral/spice never tasted so good.
Pours a clearish golden with a small white head. Aromas of grains with hoppy aromas of grass with hints of resin. Also notes of brett. Medium bodied.
750ml bottle pours out a hazy straw topped with a fluffy head. nose is great big spice some brett a little funk citrus and a berry note. Taste is more of the spice some wood nice yeast notes.
Pours a cloudy orange with lacey head. Aromas of wood, fruity notes and some funky yeast. Light berry flavors with barnyard funk and yeast.
Sampled at a tasting. Hazy orange, with a small white head. Smells of grapes, brett, vanilla and oak. Tastes like brett, slightly sour and of grapefruit and red wine. Dry, with a sour aftertaste.

Slightly hazy golden color with white head. Aroma is yeasty, fruity and also has some dank notes. Taste starts tart, fruity, floral. Finishes dry and slightly bitter. Light, effervescent body. Really good one, bright, floral and tart.
At Uber, Seattle. Hazy golden, white cream. Medium sweet brett, juicy aroma. Clean, white wine sweet. Slight fruity medicinal. Touch heavy body. Pretty tasty.
Aroma is Brett, malts/bread and spices. The flavor is spices, bread/white bread, wheat, lemon/berries and a tart/slightly funky sweet finish.
hard not to love a saison from these guys since they specialize in them. good as the rest.

Bottle, shared by me... in my dining room... just now.
On all accounts this is an old bottle. I had to dig through Facebook to see the picture of the bottle lineup from when I first got this. I donÂ’t know why itÂ’s taken me so long to open it, but the picture was from April of 2013, which puts this at three years old... maybe a touch younger. 
IÂ’ve had the beer since then, and itÂ’s a beer I like, but this rating is going off this dust bottle from my basement. 

Pours a bright orange with a huge head and nice lacing on the glass.

Goodness this smells good, lime zest, dusty attic & wet limestone basement... very nicely funky and earthy with some barnyard stuff... but impossibly bright for the age. 

The flavor is dry and tart... itÂ’s got a really nice depth of rich wine like oak and fruit character. There is some lemon zest, there is some light citrus peel bitterness... there is a little bit of apple... zippy and bright, wow. 

The palate is remarkably lively & sharp. 

IÂ’ve seen so many Brett Saisons and/or Orval-ish beers age so poorly that I didnÂ’t have a huge expectation here, but this is lovely.

Bottle courtesy of SHIG. Cheers, Shawn! Pours a hazy yellow with a white head. Nose is Brett- funk, earth, sweet malt, vinous oak, yeast, and spice. Flavor is similar with Brett, funk, earth, yeast, oak, vinous character, and spice (chamomile esque?). Medium to full in body and very memorable for a saison.

Bottle pour at Noc noc. Translucent golden / straw coloured pour with a lasting frothy white head. Aroma is lovely blend of saison yeast, bretty funk, and some peach Melba and mandarin fruits. Flavour is composed of light grains, little wheat, straw, bretty funk, peach and mango, tangy orange in the finish. Palate is light fluffy and frothy, semi drying in the finish. Very good.

750ml bottle. Hazy golden orange color with a white head. Wine orange peel yeast sweet aroma. Medium body. Carbonated. Tropical fruit floral flavor. A little bitter.

appearance: hazy orange gold, with a creamy white head and decent lacing.  aroma: citrus (orange, lemon peel), white pepper, sharp brett, light barnyard, and some jammy fruit notes.  taste: light citrus (grapefruit), raspberry, white pepper, funk, yeasty spice, a sweetness that feels like rose hips, and a general vinous undertone.  finish: the funk holds on a bit, with the sharp brett softened by the vinous sweet and sour notes; tail end is slightly astringent. notes: Really enjoyable. Alcohol well-hidden to the point of nonexistence. Another great brew by Anchorage. Split a 750, but it drinks so easy I could have had the whole thing by myself in about 20 minutes.  Bottle from Sarah for Beerdvent 2015.
750 mL bottle. Hazy Amber with a decent off-white head. Aroma is of oranges, straw, lemon, tart, and floral. Taste is of fresh orange juice, lemon, grain, white pepper, and fresh.

Bottle. The look is super hazy orange juice, off white head, and orange apricot color. The smell is tart, fruit, pickle, Brett, fresh, nice, fresh juice, and good. The taste is juicy, tart, fresh, Brett, bitter, good stuff.

750 bottle shared with czar and company. Pours a clear golden-orange with a nice white head. Aroma is clementines, wood and spices. Flavor is oranges, funky, oldish spicy and fruity. Finish is wood and tropical fruits. Lingering dusty, tart and funk. Medium body, average carbonation.

Orange gold pour, foamy off white head. Aroma of tart raspberry, barnyard, spice and grape. Flavor is hoppy, tart, spicy, of brett and wine.

750 ml.pours hazy golden with a spongy foam on top. Smells are spicy grapefruit, white grape must, resin, honey and a hint of cheese. Tastes of grapefruit, honey, white wine, berries and vanilla. Finish has oak with hints of coriander and heather. Near-medium body has medium-plus carbonation.

Keg at the CP&K, 19/11/15.
Golden orange with a decent off white covering. 
Nose is funky, light brett sticky tropical fruits, trace of yeast, farmyard light, pissy wood.
Taste comprises tarte citric rinds, funk, light floral effect, well integrated brett strokes, damp hay, barnyard, on the turn oranges, rotting peach, light acidity and balsa wood.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close laced with subtle brett pin pricks. 
Solid stuff, great balance and use of brett.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Keg at CPK as Â’Anchorage Love Buzz with brettanomycesÂ’, 8%. Hazy dark orange, opaque, small dense off-white head. Aroma is bretty, sherbet dibdab and lemon. Body is light, spritzy but not foamy. Taste is dry cardboard up front, tangy citrus, brett, sherbety lemon, sour Skittles, breathy and dusty finish with some red wine tannins. Tasty fruits and has a nice dry spiciness to it. Very good.

Bottle thanks to Bursprak! Pours hazy dark orange with a small white head. Aromas of vinegar, sour cherries, oak, brett, spices, light funk, grapefruit. Taste is oaky, vinegary, tart, tannic, white pepper, lactic tart, esters, grapefruit bitterness, vinous.

75cl bottle from MKBS, London. It pours a clean golden color with a large soapy off-white head. Aroma is strongly funky, with notes of brett, lemon, apricots, galaxy hops, white wine, lychee. Taste is lightly sweet then medium tart then lightly bitter. Quite dry. More notes of basement, lemon, apricots, galaxy hops, funk, white wine, oak. Medium bodied with creamy mouthfeel and good carbonation. Overall, complex US style saison at its best
Bottle @ Fermentoren, Aarhus. Pours hazy golden with a frothy head. Notes of white grapes, lemon rind, brett, oily, leather, oak with a citric mouthfeel.

cobrizo limpio y espuma blanca ligera. Aromas de manzana oxidada, ciruela verde, uva, pimienta negra y mohoso ligero. Cuerpo medio, inicio dulce breve que pronto pasa a un sabor cÃ­trico de brett. ligeramente picante y final seco duradero. Es una lÃ¡mbica, en realidad.

Bottle thanks to Bursprak. Pours a hazy reddish amber with a medium sized, frothy white head. Aroma has lots of oak! Spicy, dry yeast, funk, acidic, slight cheesy, peppery spicy. Taste is tart, but with a big, wheaty sweetness, dry spice, lots of oak, slight cheese again, and a bit of hops near the end. Lots of barrel character. High carbonation, but a soft, smooth body.

batch 4 may 2015. Amber pour plenty of foam. Aroma lemons, white wine, and brettanomyces. tastes like musty lemons, slight cheese dusty bretta. nice minerality. black pepper peeks out over the top. a little sharp in flavor but the alcohol is well hidden. brisk light effervescence.

750 ml. corked and caged bottle. Pours a thick, gradually collapsing fluffy, white head, with slight lacing, over a slightly hazy orange amber (SRM 9) body.....nose is light barnyard funk, slight cereal malts, hints of spice........taste is moderate barnyard, slight tart sourness, light malts, allspice, light vinous hints, mild hop/spice bitterness on the finish......mouth feel, light of medium body, mild alcohol warmth, high carbonation. The barrels are quite hidden and the spices were used with a light enough hand to produce intrigue without dominance. The Brett adds sourness and funk. The net result is a complex, refreshing beer that is thoroughly enjoyable. It is really not quite a Saison, but more of a Wild Specialty Beer (28C) under the new 2015 BJCP guidelines. BJCP 7/3/9/4/6

Backlog. 750 ml bottle shared, purchased at Supermarket Liquors. Orange and kind of hazy appearance with a fluffy and lacy white head. Tropical fruity, funky, floral, yeasty, light herbal aroma. The flavor adds some toasted grain, grapefruit, lemon zest and light hop resin. Moderately sweet and mildly bitter with a bit of acidity. Medium to full body with ample carbonation. Pretty nice overall.

Shared 750 ml. bottle poured to snifters, displaying a hazed, orangey gold color, with a healthy layer of soft white head foam, and dots & dashes of lacing. The nose was dank, bretty, light spice, and hop esters as citrus & pit fruit. The taste included dry, earthy, rind-like bitterness amped by some oaky/barrel astringency. Medium bodied, with decent carbonation, a strong, nearly abrasive Saison, where alcohol was definitely a player, and seemed more as a bretty IPA. Took a liking to it, nonetheless.
Heavy on spices and brett, with a nice bright carbonation and good fruitiness. A very, very good beer.

Bottle shared with Alex and Seb A: pineapple, barnyard, citrusy, tropical app: hazy pale thick white head t/p: thin to med body with moderate long acidic finish. O: such an amazing brew. Complex pleasing fruitiness. Better than sex. Would need to snatch some more.

750ml bottle from WilleyÂ’s Store. Batch #4. Aroma: citrus, pineapples, piney, cloves and other spices. App: hazy golden, small white head and leaving some nice lacing. Taste and palate: medium body, vinous, lots of fruits in mouth, dry light bitter finish. Overall: thatÂ’s great! Really easy to drink. Could drink this one in a record time but taking it a slowly so I can enjoy every sip. Really well balanced, great integration of the brett with the fruits. Awesome!

Bottle. Funky, peppery sour aroma. Hazy golden body with medium lasting head. Flavor begins with citrus and clove notes, followed by a champagne, grapefruit and sour hints. Long funky finish. Very crisp saison, the brett gives it a unique balance.

750 ml bottle from the Beer Authority

I was really pleased to find this. IÂ’m a substantial Anchorage fan, and a huge saison enthusiast. LetÂ’s just say it doesnÂ’t disappoint. Murky yellow-brown pour with rich orange highlighting. The nose is that distinctively Anchorage thing in which the garlic/onion/tropical fruit of new school hops merge into something that totally transcends my usual garlic sensitivity and comes of as absolutely enticing, white grapefruit and lemon and maybe a bit of pepper. The flavor is gently tart, not at all a sour ale but rather the tart style of saison, recalling Jolly Pumpkin at its best but more subtle, lemon and blood orange atop pepper and prominent (but never overdone) pinot grapes, layered with a well-integrated perfume that never comes of as gimmick or additive but rather emanates from the core of the beer. ItÂ’s beautiful. I donÂ’t usually spend 15-16 dollars per bottle these days, but this is one of the rare few not only worth trying at that price point, but worth revisiting as soon as possible. IÂ’ll be on the look out. 

tl;dr summary: Exactly the rich saison youÂ’d expect from Anchorage. And it WORKS!
(tap)(with SHIG) clear, brigh yellow colour with a small white head; aroma of funk, leather; balanced flavour with a long, light sour and bitter finish

From tap. Light hazy golden orange color with white head. Funky yeasty fruity aroma, spicy, bretty, citrusy fruity, wood, light wineous. Sweet light bitter and light acidic taste, funky yeasty citrusy fruity like aroma. Medium oily body with average carbonation.

Bottle from Tasty Beverage, Asheville. Pours orange, coppery, with a decent sized head. Smells great, with a big flowery aroma at first, then notes of tropical fruit. Some winey notes in the background. Taste is nicely tart and citrusy, with nice winey flavors. Very easy to drink. It gets winier as it warms. Hides itÂ’s ABV well, too.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2016 750 mL bottle poured into a snifter. Hazy amber body. Huge brett aroma. Strong red wine as well. Nice barrel character with some oak and vanilla.  Red wine is the first taste, as well. Sweet maltiness. Brett earthy finish softened by oak. Medium heavy. Medium carbonation. ItÂ’s all brett and red wine, which taste great together.
12 July 2015, tap at Anchorage Brewing. Orange and hazy. Nose is orange peel and faintest of Brett. Thin body and mildly fizzy. Hints of earthy cobwebs and Brett with candied orange peel. Very nice.

750 ml caged/corked bottle poured into a Spiegelau tulip. Batch 3, July 2014. Clear golden orange with 2.5 fingers of off-white head. Aromas of Brett, funk, wine, oak. Tastes of oak, herbs, dry wine, flowery and vinous notes, some white pepper, some tart acidic notes and Brett. Medium-light body with a dry finish. Too vinous for my liking.

pours unclear bright gold with a towering creamy white head, good retention and lacing. fresh and vibrant citrus, flowers - petals, spices - dill, gooseberries, cherry brettiness, smooth oak - peppery tannins, wine, very fruity and juicy, hint of woodsy vanilla, light acidity - complex microflora - some funk for sure. average to light carbonation, light body - oily; drying, smooth, gently tart and astringent herbal-spicy finish. excellent!
Gold pour white head. Peachy. Urinal cake. Bubblegum. Nectarine. A bit too chewy. Spicing mixes well. Fine, hoping for something a touch drier but beer still reps.

Fantastic stuff. Pours a dark hazy golden. Aromas of red wine, oak, funk, Belgian yeast and some spice. Flavors are tart and funky with some nice sweetness and spice. Loved this.

Pours orange/amber with hints of gold. Head in bubbly and off white and faded quickly into faint wisps and a pencil thin collar. Aroma is heavy on the Brett funk, with grass, floral hops, and lightly bready malt sweetness. I also get some orange zest. Taste is again with the brett funk up front, some citrus zestiness, very faint watermelon and fairly floral. ThereÂ’s a nice deep oakiness that works behind everything; but holds itÂ’s own. Light body, tart and bright on the tongue. Bubbly med-high carbonation.
Bottle - Nice citrus and light grassy notes, with a nice berry like sweetness. Cloudy gold with a decent white head.. Tart and vinous with a bit of bitterness. Red grape and some woody dry notes.

Batch #3. Pretty light plum purple color. Nose is floral botanicals, light red wine when warm. Heavy astringent herbal botanical character, lemon drop citrus, light red wine fruit and barrel, bitter soapy rose, bitter citrus fruit pith finish that lingers. Improved as it warmed, becoming less bitter and astringent. Not chemically astringent, but botanicals reminded me of accidentally getting some cologne or perfume in my mouth until it warmed.

750ml bottle pours toasted cloudy orange with a finger of head. Nose is full of funky floral fruit, juicy tartness, pinot noir notes, and damp wood. May 4, 2012 - with blankboy, garthicus, gregclow, jercraigs & mabel. 750ml corked & caged bottle c/o j&m.  Very hazy/cloudy amber-orange with a large frothy/foamy beige head. Batch #1, August 2011; Sampled October 2012
A steady pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a four-finger thick, pale tan colored head; it leaves lots of thick lacing clumped to the sides of my glass as it falls with lots of craggy nooks and structures. The beer is a murky, amber hue that shows a light hazed, pale amber hue when held up to the light. The aroma is lightly tart, definitively funky, phenolic, slightly medicinal, and it has a solid, grassy and cracker like malt character in the finish. This has a lightly herbal hoppiness to it that plays a supporting role in the nose. There are notes of musty white pepper notes, lots of spicy floral notes.

My first sip is dry tasting, a bit effervescent, slightly tart, with a cracker like malty finish and lots of general spiciness. There seems to be a bit of firm, astringent, spicy oak and a rounded woody flavor that pervades throughout the flavor profile. Spicy floral notes are a mix of pepper, carnation, nasturtium petals, and a touch of clove. A firm, musty, musky, phenolic Brettanomyces note perfumes this beer, though it is still smooth enough that it doesnÂ’t dominate the flavor profile here. A soft citrus character starts to come out as the beer warms and provides notes of Meyer lemon zest, a touch of tangerine zest, and maybe some tropical fruit like notes that just peak through in the finish. Nice and light bodied like a good Saison should be, in fact it is even on the light side for a Saison of this strength; making for a dangerously quaffable brew.

Not bad, but not as good as I was hoping either; I wonder if a fresher sample would be more to my liking. Still this is a more than serviceable Saison & I still want to try everything by this brewer that I can.

text: Bottle. Really pale hazy yellow pour with white head. The hops taste quite peppery, flavor which is complimented by the brett. Beautiful balance. Palate is silky and smooth and finishes very dry. Just great.

The beer appears a hazy, golden orange color with over an inch of dense, white head. The aroma offers fruit, yeast, malt, floral notes. The flavor is interesting. Floral hops come through more in the flavor than the aroma. A bit thin in the body. Slightly sweet, with additional notes of rose hips. A pretty tasty saison.

Very good, thcik, if irregularily bubbled, cream-coloured head over hazed amber beer, with a faint mossy sheen. USA-hops, citrussy, but also really lemon-liek, plus other nice aromas (rosehips?  I swear upon my black soul I wrote that before reading the contents!). Garden herbs, unripe fruit. Quite bitter & wry, very yeast-laden, yeastesters Ã  gogo. Quite some - mellow - acidiity, scarce restsugars. Strange flavours - as fruit and vegetables, not really reckoned meant for eating... drinking, then, maybe? Very present carbonation, fysical. Not a very long aftertaste, apart from some leafy bitterness backthroat, also reminiscent of orange peel mainly. Another "willed" saison. The current outlook on Saison couldnÂ’t be more wrong, IMO. This is not a bad beer by any standards, but it is a wrong saison. At least by mine...

750ml bottle.  Fruity, sweet and lightly winey aroma, some red grape, yeast funk, horseblanket, must and straw, with lighter touches of berry, oak, faintly peppery spice, light sweetness and some herbal, green, floral notes.  Lots going on here to start, for sure.  Cloudy orange in color with a foamy, sticky, uneven head and voluminous lacing.  Flavor is surprisingly sweet and fruity, only lightly funked out and Bretty, more berryish and stone fruit character throughout, faint Pinot touches, vanilla, oak and earthiness late, certainly not much in the way of bitterness to speak of although there is a very faint tartness late.  Gently bubbly mouthfeel, perhaps a bit of a syrupy feel, body is medium-full.   Very unusual and very nice.  While this was certainly enjoyable, it was a pretty recent bottling, and if I had two of them, I would be very interested to see what impact a year or so of cellar aging would have -- it seems fairly obvious that the existing sweetness may be meant to simply feed the Brett and provide some dryness and more prominent farminess, while still allowing for some residual sweetness to provide the framework.

The flavor is spicy and wild but not sour. Orange peel, florals, tropical fruit, oak and some peppery notes on the back of the tongue. It has a mildly dry, orangy, toasty leathery finish. Complex and flavorful but drinkable. Thank God the spices are very subdued. Reminds me of a funky tropical fruit drink.

750 thanks to Elwood. Absolutely the funkiest and most wild of the three Anchorages.  The barrel or added brett is pretty intense here. It dominates the saison and with whatever the spices are adds the wild character.

Bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours light amber with a thin white head. Lovely white grape and oak on the nose, a light malt base, a touch of yeast, and some mild herbal spicing. Wow...awesome nose. Taste isnÂ’t quite as good, pretty fruity, more yeast comes through, but the spicing is more intense and thereÂ’s a lot of oak astringency coming through. Thinnish and a effervescent carbonation. If this tasted like it smells, I would absolutely love it, but oh well.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2013 Bottle at home - shared with Mette (24-Jul- 2011). Cloudy amber - white head. Bretty. Lovely high bretty. Light wooden notes. Peppery. Light yeasty. Earthy. Nice bitterness. Light licorice yeadty. Bery very nice...................ReRate: Draught at CBC 2013..... Perfect balance.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden amber with a white head. Nice bold aroma of farmhouse yeast esters and white grapes. Nice medium bodied mouthfeel with an earthy texture. Flavor of pale wheat malts, perhaps with a hint of biscuit, white wine, and oak. Slightly acidid.Yeasty and peppery finish. Very complex, and quite enjoyable.

750ml from SamÂ’s, Durham. Holy cannoli, another ridiculously good beer from Anchorage. Slightly hazy deep golden pour with a frothy head, good retention and spotty lacing around the glass. Nose is terrific, with wild yeasts, lemon rind, and a lovely mellow wine barrel character. Mouthfeel is quite full but not aggressive, nicely prickly and spicy on the palate. Taste is very complex, filled with hints of what may once have been a raw profile but now filled with tangerine, lemon rind, pepper, and delicious oaked vinous character. More, please!

Pours clear amber with massive rocky head and long retention.  Aroma is assertively bretty with dry hops, tartness, dry minerality and some barrel notes.  Taste has some Pinot tannins which work nicely with the brett to produce an acidic, vinuous brew.  Body is light and frothy with palate cleansing carbonation and a crisp minerally acidic finish.  Overall, another winner from Anchorage.

Very well done.  An extremely complex beer.  The head is firm and fluffy.  Seems like a large ratio of adjunct malt are at work here, starchyness is abound.

The nose is a little one sided, with Brett battling the new world high-alpha hops.  Perhaps in time these will commingle well.

Outstanding mouthfeel, not oily but slick.  Very silky and smooth without too biting a carb to increase boyancy.  

Oak has certainly helped this massive undertaking to achieve a roundness and focus that is difficult to achieve with so many components fighting for supremacy.

Very well made beer, and a certain contender for further aging.

Pours a dark cloudy yellow with a big white head.  Aroma is a little bit of the dark side of Brett in that IÂ’m getting predominant band aid and plastic flavors, but there is some really nice subtle complexity underneath.  Some melon and light fruit, a hint of spiciness and a bit of pepper.  Jut all filtered through a band-aid.  Interestingly I shared this with a friend.  He got the top half of the bottle and I got the bottom half.  The top half was much cleaner and crisper.  The bottom half (with more of the yeast dregs?) was much more plastic and funky.  Interesting beer.

Corked and caged bomber. Pours hazy cantaloupe with a large cream-colored head with awesome retention that leaves decorative lace. The pungent brett dominates the nose. This beer is bursting at the seams with it. Dusty. Taste is lightly sweet and nice and meaty; dry and refreshing. This is delicious. I want a whole case of it for my beer fridge.

750ml bottle purchased at binnyÂ’s lp....pours a hazy deeper than apricot copper hued liquid and topped with a creamy vividly white head... aroma is focused on floral notes to go alongside belgian yeast esthers. a fair bit of grape and bretty dryness open up and become more prominent as the beer warms. the brett and its pineapple nature definetely serves as a stronghold... flavors are floral and semi-fruity with the yeast profile but then immediately evolve into a bretty wine barrel influenced combination of light berry, more along the strawberry side while finishing on a spicy semi-astringent bitter note. body is light and fluffy with adequate carbonation but iÂ’m a fair bit sensitive to the astringent bitterness on the backend.

750ml, caged and corked bottle. Poured a golden color with an averaged sized head. Aromas of spices, wood, musty, some funk, pile of straw, and light citrus. Tastes of citrus, vinous, spices, and brett.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2012 750 ml corked and caged bottle purchased at Royal, in Kansas City, Missouri.  The pour is a hazed orange, with a thick one inch slightly off white head which is lasting.  The aroma is Brett earthiness, light resinous lemon citrus, wood, and a toasted malt character.  The aromas are nicely vinbrant, well balanced - the Brett plays nicely with all else. The taste is similar tot he nose, with the Brett present, nicely accenting the citrus grapefruit hop notes, and the earthy toasted malt which carries some sweetness that was not noticeable in the nose.   The finish is long, and reveals a bit of pepper character, along with some lemon peel.  The palate is medium bodied dries out a ton on the end.  The alcohol is present in the dry finish, detracting a bit.  Nice all around beer, though certainly not a typical Saison.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange golden caramel with a thick and creamy cream colored head.  Lots of lacing.  Aroma of Brett yeast, sour oak wood,  wine barrels and spices.  Taste of Brett yeast, sour oak wood, spices and wine barrels.

Pours a cloudy orange color with a nice head to it. Has a bretty, floral smell to it. Taste is similar but with some oak in there and bitterness that last through out. Pretty nice but I would like to see what the brett does to this in another year.

Bottle.  Pours a rusty brown color with a thick lasting head on top.  Some decent lacing sticks to the sides of the glass the whole way through.  The aroma, surprisingly, is somewhat reminiscent of the Bitter Monk Belgian I had not too long ago from these guys.  Lots of french oak and wine character.  IÂ’m picking up a lot of white grape though, not unlike a scent found in something aged in chardonnay.  Citrus peel, flowers, lavender, and funky "wild" yeast join in to a really nice scent.  Smells a touch more hoppy too than expected but IÂ’ve got no issue with that.  The flavors are lightly spiced with lavender and chamomile.  Again, thereÂ’s lots of oak and wine here.  Pinot Noir is red, right?  For some reason this smells and tastes like itÂ’s been aged in white wine.  ThatÂ’s not a bad thing, just an observation.  I actually think more of a more berry flavor wouldnÂ’t work as well in this.  The finish shows bitter citrus hops with some notes of resin too.  The 8% doesnÂ’t completely hide but this is very drinkable and doesnÂ’t have any of that overly sweet, tangy, and alcoholic flavors often found in higher abv Saisons.  ItÂ’s an interesting take on a Saison but is complex, drinkable, and very tasty.  I would have never guessed this beforehand but I like the Bitter Monk more than this.  Regardless, this is a great beer and I am really impressed by this new brewery.  I canÂ’t wait to try their next offerings!

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2012 Bottle @ home, courtesy of gooovikings. Thanks Jetson! Batch 1. The highlight and the finale of my impromptu Monday night beer tasting. Somewhat cloudy, a touch burnt orange appearance with an off white head. Somewhat spicy, tangy, vinous, bretty, tart citrusy, ilight barnyard, Belgian yeasty aroma. Tart, bretty, citrusy, Belgian yeasty, vinous, spicy/peppery, tangy, slightly floral flavor with a dry, spicy finish. A touch tangy, tart citrusy aftertaste. Pretty cool beer. (3.8)Bottle in Vail, shared with Jetson for Christmas. Batch 2. Pours a milky, dark orange appearance with an off white head. Zippy, zesty, spicy vinous, organic/herbal, dark berry aroma. Pretty funky, grainy straw, white peppery, tart grape, dry oaky, vanilla flavor that dries out a bunch on the finish. (4.0)

Bottle.

Head is initially large, frothy, rocky, white, fully lasting.
Body is hazy light amber, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain), moderately hoppy (resin, grapefruit), lightly to moderately yeasty (cobwebs, barnyard), with notes of alcohol, menthol, gum, lemon zest, oak, sour apple, band-aid, pepper.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately acidic, moderately to heavily bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

A difficult beer to rate, since itÂ’s not really a saison (too big and boozy), and IÂ’m also not fond of raw/green hop odor.  But then again it doesnÂ’t fail the style in the other usual ways, so itÂ’s not too hard to mostly forgive its New World aggressiveness.  Think of this more like an Americanized tripel, but one thatÂ’s dry and yeasty like it should be, not syrupy sweet and banana-heavy like most American examples.  A "super saison" if you prefer, but IÂ’ve never liked that term for the same reason "Imperial mild" is silly.  Credit to the aroma for sure, itÂ’s complex and rustic...wild, woody, and quite enjoyable other than the crude hop stink (the aroma could easily score a nine if only the hops were less brutish).  I would have guessed white wine barrels, though...I get absolutely none of the usual pinot noir fruit character like strawberry, raspberry, cranberry, etc.  And thankfully the added spices are difficult to pick out, even though thereÂ’s a vague sense that itÂ’s not adjunct-free.  Very dry in the mouth despite having plenty of starting sweetness...itÂ’s big, but at least the finish is clean and bitter.  Very noticeable alcohol burn, but not out of the norm for being 8%.  Overall I like it quite well as a Belgian-styled strong ale, but I am naturally disappointed that it isnÂ’t a saison. Also, the fact that this is $16 means I will never buy another bottle (Saison Dupont is almost half that, as one example...I realize this is barrel aged, but would I rather drink Dupont regardless of price? definitely).  ItÂ’s obvious the brewer has it in him to make a decent straight-up saison, though, and I hope he does so one day (and prices it more properly).
bottle, thanks to ericandersnavy, dense color of orange marmalade, has a really nice bretty tropical aroma with flavors of pine needles, chalky sour fruits, really good

750 ml. Cloudy, deep gold body. Off-white, fizzy head. Big aroma of grapefruit, mustiness, lacquer, citrus, spice, orange peel. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. It finishes lightly sweet and moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. The funky brett combined with citrus results in a taste of grapefruit on the edge of being overripe. Hints of biscuit, oak. Too juicy in the finish for a saison. But style aside, this is an interesting beer. And really enjoyable to drink. Thanks wnoble.

Pours hazy and medium light amber with some creamy head. Nose immediately brings on musty, spice, and funky Brett with, a good blend of resinous dank and citrusy orange hops. Flavor is sweet but finishes dry. Again musty and woody wine barrels. This one is really nice.

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours cloudy yellow with white fizzy head. Aroma is nice, notes of farmhouse and lemon, light must and earth. Flavor has a light sweetness but much the same, nice balanced bitter. Overall, solid brew!

Deep honey hue with hints of tangerine at its core and an eggshell head.  Lots of coiander and peppery spice accompanied by lemongrass, grapefruit pith, tropical fruit, wine, and funk.  Perhaps it had a hard time playing with the other stellar beers of the night but wasnÂ’t blown away by it.
Amazing brew. Really really amazing brew. Pours really hazy. Wonderful aroma. Tart fruits. Smells like a Flanders red. Wonderful fruit and yeast flavor. I find this hard to describe. So great.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2012 750mL bottle, pours a cloudy orange amber with a beige head. Aroma of orange peel / zest, some tropical fruits, some white wine qualities and coriander. Flavour is quite vinous and fruity, with white wine oak upfront, balanced beautifully by intense tropical fruits, some orange / lemon zest and typical Belgian yeast. Delicious mixture of flavours - awesome saison.

Bottle-Damn, this is impressive!  Pours dark hazy orange with a big fluffy soapy white big bubble head.  The aromas here are amazing-lots of woody brett notes, dry grapes, lite pheonlic spice, Brett funk, lots of wood and spice.  Alot going on here.  Flavors exhibit the woody notes up front along with lite sourness, nice spicy saison character, lots of brett, tart white whine like flavors with a very dry finish.  The pinon nore barrel really shows here-lots of dry wood tones with the added brett, this beer finishes really dry with some liter bitterness from the spice and maybe a dab of hops as well.  Long into the finish, the toasted oak shows up even more.  Could be the best saison i have ever had.  This thing is amazing!

Pour is a nice peachy color with a large white head.  Aroma is sour from the pinot.  Then comes some yeast and citrus fruit.  Flavor is sour tart fruit to start then comes some stong but not overpowering pepper.  Finish has more tart fruit and a nice vanilla.  ItÂ’s kinda like a sour\saison hybrid and it works.
Black Friday tasting and a nice damn beer! Good peppery aroma, earthy, soil, light funk and some oaky notes.  Flavor is dry, funky, light oak, pepper, light yeast.

Pours a soft hazy straw yellow with two fingers of creamy off white head. Nose is very nice, lots of funky and horsey notes with a light acetic character and a subtle vinous feel. Lightly peppery and tropical. Dry and peppery mouthfeel. Notes of lemongrass and citrus rind with some tannic bite. Lightly oaky.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy light amber with a one finger white head with good retention that leaves a moderate amount of lacing on the glass.  The aroma is some brett funk, a lot of grape and red wine, black pepper, and some apple.  The initial taste is sweet with apple and apricot, then some red wine and barrel comes through with a peppery note, some brett, and some yeastiness.  The finish is moderately dry.  Medium body.  Medium-high carbonation.  An enjoyable saison.  I would have preferred it to be slightly drier overall.  It doesnÂ’t quite reach the height of their Bitter Monk, but still a good beer.

Bottle shared at the 6th annual Richmond Industry Gathering, 11/27/11. Pours a hazy peach color with a medium sized creamy head. Good head retention. Aroma of peppery, earthy and fruity notes with a bit of breadiness. The taste is bread, pineapple, buttery notes and spicy hops. Full bodied. Nice.

Bottle at Black Friday tasting. Lemon rind. Nicely dry. Green apple. Some wet dog and socks.
Hazy yellow orange in color... Aroma of Pinot noir and sour wild yeast... Flavor is coriander, spices and citrus notes of Pinot noir grapes with a finish of wild yeast sourness... Delicious

Poured a hazy full straw almost golden to orange color. The head was at least on full inch, continuous lacing. The aroma was coriander and oranges and yeast and other spices. The flavor followed and included wonderful tannins and oak and rich pinot notes. IÂ’m a sucker for pinot, in many ways, but anchorage did a nice job with this one, and it did great for our highly intoxicating Thanksgiving assortment of alcohol. Body medium to full. Go, Flacco!

750ml to the face, white wine glass. Pours a murky sandstone colour with a frothy beige head that retains well and shows good cling as the head fades. The nose is rustic, dusty and full of oak character. The grape notes to me come across almost more like a pinot grigio than a chardonnay, but whatever, still bright, pungent and enticing. Oh man this is tasty! On the palate, oak and peppery notes stay in the forefront while on the back end, a lingering of vanilla and wine notes suggestive of Gurwitz Terminer. Passion fruit and complex citrus notes emerge with greater presence as it warms. All the intermingling flavours and aromas are delicately balanced, yet the overall network of zesty citrus, peppercorn, funk, oak and saison yeast filth is one of tremendous intensity. The finish is slightly astringent, though this is characteristic of the blend of stains employed and only adds to the dryness of the finish, making the beer effectively more quenching and sessionable (if only I could afford this as an everyday session ale *sigh*). The mouthfeel is velvety, even moreso as it warms, with lively carbonation and a long duration. If only all things to come from Alaska were this awesome.

Murky glowing orange/amber with a frothy white head.  Aroma is dry spices, brett, melon (perhaps peach), and a touch of oak.  Taste is dry and clean with mixed spices, brett, pepper, and dry oak with a lingering bitterness.  The body and mouthfeel on this beer is spot on.  Excellent beer and certainly one I need to grab a second bottle of for some time in the cellar.

Pours slightly hazed amber into a snifter. Off-white head with good retention recedes leaving spot lacing to skim surface. Summer fruit and earthy funk aromas. Crisp with sweet caramel upfront turning to tropical fruit before the lasting brett finish.

750ml big thanks to pintplease.
Appearance : Hazy pale amber with big foamy and creamy head. Lots of lacing.

Aroma : Big brett with nice spices and wood. Very nice fruity notes. Light citrusy and light leathery notes. Nice herbal hops.

Palate : Carbonation is very soft. A little bit too soft for me especially near the end of the glass.

Taste : Lots of brett with spices. Big fruity brett on finish with leather and wood. Barnyard. Very fruity, nice hops. Nice herbal notes. Light tropical fruits. Finish is a bit sticky and resinous.

Overall : Wow what an elegant beer. Very complex, very nicely balanced. Awesome brett profile with great hops. Very cohesive, nothing is overpowering. Very dry and rather drinkable at first. At the end it got a bit too much with the hops and the big brett. I think the lack of carbonation made it a bit cloying after half the bottle (we were two on it). Still an amazing beer. Really complex, really well made. IÂ’m impressed.

Bottle. Moderate aromas all around, with malt notes of grain and straw, flowers for the hops, barnyard and musty for the yeast, and background notes of grape, wood, berry and a huge mix of spices like allspice, cardamom, mace and cinnamon. Head is huge, creamy turing rocky, mostly white with excellent lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is hazy yet sparkling amber. Flavor starts lightly sweet and lightly to moderately acidic, then finishes lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter and sour. Palate is on the lighter side of medium, slippery, with a lively carbonation and has a lightly astringent finish. Great aromas and great balance in this Saison, and the barrrel aging is very noticable.

This is my favorite of the three available in SoCal.  Nice wood barrel notes contrast against the sharp grape/wine character.  Some pepper notes linger as well.  Pours a red/orange color.  Big Belgiany yeast aroma and barnyard flavors too.

Brilliant copper kettle color with lasting off white foam. Awesome dry wood, barnyard piss and dung, dry spice, dusty pale malt aromas. Light to medium body with average co2. Big citrusy hop flavors with dusty pale malt, dry hay, dry spice, rose hips, other herbs--very tasty Saison
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Tasted on 11/13/11 from a corked and caged 750mL bottle purchased at BinnyÂ’s Lincoln Park.  Pours cloudy, dark orange with a very thick white head that slowly recedes to a thin layer of even lace.  The nose is tart red berry fruits, very dry, funky yeast, a bread malt aroma, and some nice spiciness.  The flavor is, once again, very dry and funky with a nice spicy character, bread malt, and a very balanced red berry flavor.  The body is medium with lively carbonation, and a long, funky, earthy yeast, and lightly bitter finish.

Brett bomb with a good saison behind it. Good spices, fruity. Somewhat sweet in the finish. Only a little yeasty.Very generous head of foam.  Very drinkable.Above average mouthfeel. A little funky aroma. Bottle from Bierkraft $21.46.

Bottle.  Starts with a gorgeous pour...hazed dirty orange color with thick, dense, and quite lacy cream colored head.  Nose is quite nice as well...really get the pinot barrel influence coming through here..grapey and a bit earthy over some saison/belgiany yeast tones.  Flavors bring forth a lot of the pinot grapey/oaky nuances and combine them with a nice, spicy yeast character and a relaxingly crisp saison-esque, spritzy body.  Remarkably light and refreshing for something boasting 8% alcohol. Whatever spices were used certainly do not come forth very strong or overpowering, which in my opinion, is a great thing.  The brett is subtle but you can tell itÂ’s really helping bringing out that oaky vinous quality.  IÂ’ve heard all the hype of these guys and to be honest, iÂ’m starting to recognize that itÂ’s well deserved.  These guys are definitely a solid addition to the craft beer world.  Nicely done....canÂ’t wait to try more from them.

My Bottom Line :  
This bountiful Wild SaisonÂ’s floral intricacies lean into tropical fruitiness and pine-y brettanomyces, while oak tannins tag along the enjoyable dryness. 

Further Personal Perceptions :  
-A sheet of foam crowns the misty pale amber.
-This rivals some of Jolly PumpkinÂ’s best efforts, execution-wise, for a Wild Ale.
-Effervescence could have been higher for such a brew. Although that would have made it dangerously easy to forget about the alcohol touch.
-The flavor profile is highly cohesive even with all the variables in play. Great complexity and harmony.
-The resinous hop bitterness is well levelled with the rest of the brewÂ’s moderately high intensity.
-I canÂ’t really perceive the Pinot Noir signature in here, but the oaken sagacity is perceivable.

Bottle.

750ml bottle purchased at The Davis Beer Shoppe.  Wow, the aroma on this is really buggy with tart hints of brett and likely some pedio, too.  Some sour green apple hints, and maybe some light oakiness in the nose.  Underneath all of this, there is a stale urine character, which is a bit off-putting.  Mostly opaque honey-colored body with a large, off-yellow head that leaves decent lacing behind.  Starts pretty harsh and tart, with some bitter olive juice characteristics.  The softens just a little bit towards the middle, and a scant amount of spiciness presents itself along with some yeast esters.  Finishes bitter and dry.  Imagine eating a mouthful of cheap pimento olives that are just a little sour, and you have this beer.  Not sure why this is considered a saison on this site, when itÂ’s clearly a wild ale with saison as a base beer.

Bottle. Amber beerw ith a cream colored head. Malt and spice aroma with floral notes and red wine barrel. Red grape and oak flavor with malt floral tones, yeast, and spice. Mediumb odied. Red wine and floral tones linger with yeast, malt, and spice.

Bottled sample shared with oakbluff. Orange in colour with strong carbonation. BIg time bretty funk on the nose, along with notes of dried herbs, mellow red wine, and citrus peel. Very dry in the mouth with loads of brett, rose hip herbal tea, orange and tangerine peel, and red wine barrel. A bit like Orval, but with more barrel and additional spices. Really good stuff.

750 ml bottle.   Opaque amber pour with a big, thick rocky white head.  Aroma of strong, earthy brett, leather, dry leaves.  Some oak, bright woody sweetness, honey.  Some apparent tannins as well.  Flavor is dry, earthy, with lots of nice brett notes.  Some funky leather and barnyard.  Mild oak, some grapes and sweetness from the pinot noir.  The tannins really start coming out as it warms.  Funky, dusty berries, some wet wool.  This is one of the tastiest saisons IÂ’ve ever had.  Medium bodied, lots of carbonation.  This beer is an absolute symphony to brett.  Lovely, lovely beer.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors. It pours a cloudy brown with a lasting off finish white head. The nose has spicy , earthy, and herbal notes. The flavor has some white wine, light notes of herbal hops, some pine resin. The are also some florals and some light sweetness. A nice mix of flavors that evolve as the brew warms. Light in body with higher carbonation leading to a dry finish. A very nice divergence on the style. Recommended.

750ml Bottle: Got in trade from phaleslu; THANKS Peter!  Aroma of Brett, citrus, grass, light wood, slight melon, pepper, and some malt.  Poured orange in color with a medium-sized, creamy, dense, off-white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny and small particles throughout.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is medium sweet and medium bitter.  Tastes of Brett, hops, citrus, wood, fruit, slight melon, and pepper.  Medium body.  Tingly, gassy, then dry texture.  Lively carbonation.  Medium sweet, medium to heavily bitter, Brett, citrus, hops, wood, pepper, finish is dry.  8%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Batch 1, August 2011. 

Pours a completely opaque, dark golden orange color with a frothy, pillowy 2.5 finger white head that has very good retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap. Streaks and splotches of soapy lacing left behind. 

Earthy, slightly funky aroma with lots of barn/farmhouse character along with some prominent brett and zesty spice. ThereÂ’s also some sweet fruit notes but the barrel presence is subtle. Musty bretty funk compliments the saison yeast nicely. Hints of eatery fruits and bready yeast along with some pepper and coriander. IÂ’m picking up a vinous presence that compliments the eatery fruit presence. Subtle earthy oak with hints of cherry, strawberries, grape and other dark fruit. Very complex nose but could use a bit more barrel in the nose. 

Medium bodied but on the fuller end with a slight creamy texture that is countered by the funky/sour character. Lots of musty funk/dry brett flavor that melds with the saison/farmhouse yeast pretty well. Slightly puckering but more dry and funky than tart. Much more so than I expected resulting in a dryness that is exaggerated by the berrel notes. Dry toasted oak with a faint vinous red wine character that gives off hints of grape, strawberry and other dark fruits. Pretty complex but the funk/brett donates slightly overpowering the eatery fruit notes and Pinot noir elements. Pretty good with a well masked ABV but could use bit more balance. IÂ’m glad I got to try this one and am looking forward to sampling more from this brewery.

Bottle; Pour is murky golden with an above average off white head in this glass - retention rate is average I suppose - with some light lacing present as well. This is an interesting brew - but IÂ’ll be frank - I was expecting more. The nose is spicy / peppery, with an earthy character from the oak - while providing some saison notes of lemongrass and mild belgian yeast. The flavor profile has more of the fruity citrus notes - leading into heavy spices and oak, while a certain sweetness comes into play that I didnÂ’t pull from the nose. The brett did honestly hit me fairly heavily out of the gate, but I felt like I adjusted to it fairly well going forward. This one finishes quite dry - so I suppose there is a lot of elements here; the brett being the big one - yet it doesnÂ’t feel quite balanced - by my estimation.

Pour is dark orange with a slight red tinge. Finger-wide head that fades quickly but leaves nice lacing and a ring. Aroma is of barnyard funk with some leather, citrus, and lighter fruits. Flavor is of apple peel, orange peel, leather, musk, and spices. Sharp, boozy finish, lingering and dry.

75cl bottle.  Large off-white head that leaves nice lacing, hazy amber body.  Aroma is medium sweet, herbal/spicy, dusky, vinous, Brett, some pepper.  Taste is moderately sweet, vinous, Brett, herbal/grapefruit, some dusky, pepper.  Medium body, some effervescence/acidity.

Hazy golden color with a large white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of brett, wood, vanilla, spice, citrus, wine, and some toasted malts. Taste of brett, vanilla, spices, wine, citrus, hay, toast, and light sourness in the finish.

750ml bottle.  Pours a hazy, dusky, deep burnt orange amber color with a thick, stubborn head of spongy, beige tinted froth.  Slowly, the foam settles to a thin, swirly film with a pronounced edge.  Thick, hard, sticky cobweb lacing coats  early the wntire glass.  After warming up a bit, gorgeous aromas of dusty, peppery, earthen brett and dried pineapple flesh are met with old oak and mild red grape tannins.  Hints of tart cherry skin emerge from the Pinot-soaked depths.  Bready, caramelized Malta are honey-kissed but well attenuated, providing an ample, softly biscuity backdrop for the zesty, floral Belgian yeast and earthy brett.  The more it warms, the more vinous it becomes.  At times it reminds me of SupplicationÂ’s big, bretty, much less sour cousin.  The flavor tows a similar line, earthy as hell and very spicy and peppery.  I detect hints of rose hips and hibiscus flower in the prominent yeast profile.  Malts are dry, toasted, and crackery, hinting also at very well attenuated biscuit.  A grassy-floral hop bite is more prominent than the nose suggests.  Vinous character is toned down, as is the oak, in comparison with the nose.  The palate is weighty, yet dry, enlivened by zippy, almost stinging carbonation.  Bitter botanicals and floral hops intensify greatly on the finish, lingering well after the swallow.  Overall, itÂ’s a damn fine beer.  IÂ’d like to see things toned down a bit almost across the board (alcohol, brett, spice, hops), which would make it a bit more palatable and allow the Pinot Noir flavors to shine a bit more.  IÂ’m splitting hairs now, of course.  Great brew.

I donÂ’t really understand the fascination with Anchorage Brewing.  The description of their beers makes them seem BIG AND BAD.  However, when you taste them, they are actually pretty lame.  NOT to say that they are bad beers, but their tastes and flavor experiences DO NOT reach the expectation set by the descriptions.  They are barely sour at all, despite Brett being the "king".  Other than that, they are just intensely drinkable high alcohol content beers.  Definitely not worth the price.

(750ml bottle, courtesy of BMan1113VR )  Pours a cloudy orange body with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of florals, orange, grapefruit, oak, and pepper.  Flavor of oak, florals, brett, grass, celery, orange peel, pinot, pineapple, passion fruit, and pepper.  Excellent!

Sampled at the DC Ratebeer Gathering.  Pours a translucent, dark yellow with a thin, creamy white head.  Nice nose, grassy, herbal, sage, white grape, yeast, a little funk.  Flavor is sweet, a little horsey, grass, lemon peel, lightly medicinal, a little sugary, wormwood.  Medium bodied, dry finish.

bottle... dark gold, copper deep in the middle, a big off white head, good retention, spotty lace... the aroma is too much bretty it just dominates everything, light oak and red wine, and a weird off note of rotten eggs underlies everything, I try to ignore it, bu it is off-putting...  the taste is a brett bomb as well, the pinot doesnÂ’t compliment the bret, its makes it more yeasty and tannic, too musty... a decent saison but just doesnÂ’t come together as well it as it sounds, perhaps in time this will be better

Bottle: &nbsp Cloudy orange, dirty, huge frothy white head, very sticky lacing. &nbsp Bright floral nose, sweet tropical fruit, citrusy, just plain ole sexy! &nbsp Bright barnish notes up front, a little alcoholic like floralness, the fruitiness is there but not as strong as the nose suggested. &nbsp Pretty tasty nonetheless. &nbsp On second thought, I am getting some candied apple peel with this one. &nbsp Spices are starting to emerge as it warms. &nbsp The aroma... yeah, fantastic. &nbsp Very pale vinous and oak characters on the backside. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full. &nbsp The alcohol becomes a bit more noticeable on the finish, but its still within check. &nbsp This is very much like an Imperial Saison, and I am loving it. &nbsp Nice work Gabe!

Bottle.  Pours a deep and cloudy amber brown with a large creamy beige head.  Sweet brett notes hit once the cork is pulled, getting a little earthier and deep once itÂ’s in the glass.  Spicy brett, sweet light heather notes, a touch floral.  Medium bodied, lightly sweet at the start, picking up a healthy amount of brett and a very light black pepper note.  DoesnÂ’t entirely dry out, lingering brett developing a touch of vanilla, caramel, and a soft sweetness.  Another amazing beer from Anchorage.

Bottle. Pour is murky gold with a good white head, good lacing/retention. Aroma is brett, fruity/floral hops, lemons, pinot grapes, grain husk. Taste is moderately bitter, tart, pepper, oak, tropical fruit, grass. Palate is light, oily, tart, with a bitter finish. Very nice.

Bottle from Healthy Spirits. Pours cloudy golden with a rich off-white head and a fruity aroma. There is a fruity malt flavor that has a nice yeast presence and an oaky finish. This is not a sour version of saison but, rather, a hearty spicy version, and is very pleasant to drink.

25.4 oz bottle.  Murky light brown with a pocked white head.  Nose is grass, candi and oak with vinous hints.  Sudsy medium body; yeasty and resiny.  Taste is lemon, honeydew and candi with hints of elderberry and Pinot Noir.  Would have liked to pick up more of the spices.

[Bottle, thanks Guerde!] Pours hazy orange with a small off-white head. Aroma is oak, funky brett, coriander, light citrus, and red grape. Taste is lightly tart and funky, lots of peach, alcohol fairly obvious, but not too overdone, underlying malt, coriander, big oak character again--some pinot this time. Medium-mouthfeel, dry, long finish. Overall, a solid saison, and enjoyable to drink. Thanks again, Andy!

Sampled at an esbls tasting.  This is dingy golden with a soapy white head.  A funky fruity bretty nose.  First sip is spicy and it is funky, too.  The spicesvare pepper and fall.  This is interesting and very unique.  I like it.

Bottle from SamÂ’s, shared with my wife on our anniversary, outside, in front of a fire, and already a bit tipsy.  Pours hazy orange with (I thought) a bit of a pink tint.  Lovely sudsy, big white head and nice lacing.  Nose of brett, lemons, tropical fruit, orange, hibiscus and roses.  Bit of wood as well.  Taste adds more depth and a nice malt character to back it all up and a white pepper and hop bitterness.  Lively mouthfeel and great beer.  CanÂ’t wait to try more from this brewery.

murky gold, frothy large bubbled white head, thick ring lasts. Phenolic, goaty, brett nose, lightly salty and sour green apple. Flavor very husky, light grass and lemon, bit clashing in the nose, flavor more consistent but very husky. Dry finish, bitterness soapy.

Sampled on 10/8/2011. This saison pours a slightly hazy orange gold color from a 750ml corked and caged bottle. Medium to large sized white foamy head with good retention and long lasting lacing. The aroma is fruity, musty, oaky, spicy and bretty. A medium bodied saison. The malts are fruity and sweet. Lots of citrus, grapefruit and tangerine, yeast and oak. The hops are herbal and citrusy. Nice carbonation. Lots of flavors here, wood, brett, yeast, spices, some must and funk. All the flavors are nicely balance, making this a very easy to drink saison. Very nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean, smooth and a touch dry. Aftertaste is slightly bitter and spicy.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 Bottle (batch #1) to snifter. Pours pale amber with a large fluffy foamy head that fades to a film and shows some lacing. Aroma is fruity tart and funk with some cork as well. Taste is funky cardboard and sour bitterness with floral and fruity flavors along with grape peel and appricot. Palate is medium and chaulky with an abundance of fizz and finishes dry. Very nice!

Bottle (batch 1) sample thanks to portableparty!  Slightly hazy orange pour, decent amount of carbonation/head and an aroma of lemon and farmhouse aromas.  Flavor is slightly sour lemon, spicy white pepper and a little bit of wine/vinegar.  Very good!
Funky brett nose with lots of pineapple and apricots. The taste is light to moderately sweet, lightly tart, lots of peppery yeast,  some flowers, and juicy pineapple.

Pours a slightly hazy golden with a stringy lacing white head.  Has a sweet biscuity pale malty nose with some light citrus and coriander.  Starts with good fullness and effervescent carbonation along with a biscuity maltiness and authentic grassy hop bitterness before a drier bittersweet finish.  True to style and drinkable.

Bottle shared by GT2.  Pours hazy and lightly cloudy orange with a medium-small, bubbly white head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is funky and earthy, farmhouse yeast with medium fruity esters, light sugar notes, and lightly stale earthy hops.  Some vinous notes come in around the fruity esters.  Flavor is light hay and straw malt, vinous character and fruity esters, funky barnyard yeast, lightly tart and a dry finish.  Medium body medium warmth, and carbonation.

Pale orange in color.  Citrusy tropical fruit, perfume/flowers, pinot, barnyard, and spice.  Yeasty tropical fruit, pinot, spice, with a light tart acidity.  Clean and semi-dry.  A little fuller on the palate than expected.  Tart acidity and pinot/wine taste lingers.  While the wine barrel notes are nice, it lends a similar profile to this beer as it does to their Whiteout Wit.  I could see myself getting tired with the parallel taste profile.  Nonetheless, looking forward to trying more of their stuff.

750 mL bottle. Pours an opaque amber with a pinkish hue. Nose holds really impressive honeydew and cantaloupe melon, grape bubblegum, further tropical fruit like pineapple, and good brett presence. Flavor brings more cheesecloth and acidity to the foreground, with further kiwi, mango, dry pepperiness, and sourness. Also a really cool cedar component. This brewery is killing it right now. Awesome stuff.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2012 Pours deep orange with a big sudsy off white head.  Lots of lace and great retention overall.  Nose is tropical fruits, pepper, brett, citrus, cherry,rose petals.  Flavor is bretty, rose, some tropical fruit and citrus bitterness in the finish with a bit of pepper and other spices.  Quite impressive just like the ipa.

Thanks Carl! An orange hazy pour with a pink tinted white head. Where to start...there really is so much going on in this masterful concoction. Pineapple and big league chew provide the backbone of the nose, with herbal hops and starfruit providing an excellent background. More tropical fruits in the flavor, with nectar, dough, cheesecloth, and earthen brett making a presence. Dry as hell with great effervescence.

750mL thanks to craftycarl21. Pours a hazy peach to light orange color- nice SRM- with a big, yellowish head. Nice retention and lace. Nose is quite incredible. I really canÂ’t believe it but just an explosion of tropical melon, really like dragonfruit and jackfruit and cantaloupe all combined. Small peppery/spicy notes come through. Dry hopping seems to have annihilated any floral Brett component. Taste is interesting: lots of cedar, spicy wood, cracker, leather, dry from the Brett fermentation. Quenching, dry palate. Very good. Hard to follow up Civil Disobedience with any beer but this one can do it. IÂ’m just not sure if this will be one to age or not given its tropical hop nose. Perhaps with age it will become Brett forward instead, but it may not have that Brett + tropical hop duo that makes this such a treat. Get ready for the hype train because this is the real deal.

Cloudy orange color, large off white head that settles quickly and leaves solid lacing. Aroma of citrus > grass > fruit. Taste is barnyard lemons, straw and hay with sour peppers toward the finish. Very nice stuff.

Bottle. Nice finger and a half of a creamy foamy white head that provides good lasting power and spotty lacing; very hazy murky brown-tinged orange.  Citrus and barnyard funk in the aroma with a slight doughy sourness.  Lots of nice fruitiness, earth, touch of herbs, funk, and vinous notes in the flavor.  Medium to lighter body with vibrant, sparkling carbonation.  Lovely.

750ml bottle. Hazy orange/amber with a thick off white head that simmers to a spotty film. Aroma of orange peel, biscuit dough, light perfume, black pepper and just a very faint oaky, earthy, brett scent. The flavor is extremely well balanced, some sweetness from the malt, zesty spices, light hop bitterness and light sour yeast, no alcohol taste. Medium body with average carbonation and a smooth, soft mouth feel. This beer is excellent fresh, the brett is barely noticeable now and I really wonder how this will taste as the brett takes hold.

Pours a hazy orange color with a white head.  Sour smelling.  Weird.  Tastes like bark.  Tree bark.  Like a hoppy farmhouse ale.  Weird to be considered a saison.  Guess there is a bit of spice but meh.

Poured a very hazy orange color with a creamy white head that faded quickly.  Aroma is very nice like a well blended lambic.  Very floral with some sweet orange hints.  Taste is creamy and slightly tart and fruity.  Transitions into a very dry hoppy finish with orange flavors.  Overall this beer is a huge surprise.  Very unique and delicious.  Great!

Bottle picked up on whim at DeCicios in Ardsley. Pours cloudy dirty orange with small head.  Great nose of grapefruits, spice and sour patch kids.  Tastesnof tart cherries, Pinot noir aging comes thriught, pepper, grass, and floral notes. Lively carbonation and quick drying on palate although flavor lingers.  Reall really good.

750 c&c from The Davis Beer Shoppe in Davis, CA. This place has lots of good beer!!! Pours hazy dark amber with a frothy/foamy off-white head. Aroma through the foam is celery and very mucky barnyard. Followed by fruity perfume? Med + body. Flavor is celery, barnyard, red wine, funk, barnyard, yeast/spice, oak, French shoes(:)) This is fruity, juicy funky stuff. This is rich vinosity hitting farm yard. My mouth tingles. My nose rejoices. Where do these guys come from?

750ml bottle, purchased at Pangaea in Sacramento. Pours a murky, dark orange-brown color; fine-bubbled light-tan head with solid retention and lacing. Lots of red berries, vanilla, light citrus notes, and a mild brettiness; lightly funky and fruity and creamy. Medium body; medium-high carbonation; light red wine notes, creamy texture, a modestly developed brett character thatÂ’s more lime and crackery than overt tartness; nice heavily berry character with very light tannins, almonds, a touch coarse but damn tasty. Medium finish: bretty, crackery, some lasting berry notes.

Bottle (Batch #1, August 2011). Pours with a hazy, deepish gold body with a large and lasting, fluffy off-white head. Great lace. Aromas amazingly good! Right off the bat: fresh tangerine/grapefruit juice. Good acidity, a little funk, red wine, tropical fruit hop notes, CITRA! Smells a little bit like Le Terroir with the hop and funk note. Sweet, perfume, floral, estery. Light bready malt. Very fragrant, pineapple. Amazing! Flavors are funky as well, juicy, oak, barrel, red wine, fruit,  floral, a bit grassy. A touch grainy, bready and straw like. Surprisingly bitter (both hop and tannin). Nice tropical fruit, grassy hop notes, some pepper, rich yet delicate, lots of nice tropical brett C esters. Lingering, slightly acidic stonefruit. Blown away, this is OUTSTANDING! Lively, playful carbonation, lingering funk, nice tannin, lightly warming, creamy bubbles. Balanced and complex.

This might be one of my new favorite breweries.

Pour amber with a light reddish/orange hue and a good sized off-white pillowy head.  The aroma has lots of peach, tartness, peppery spice, floral powderiness, hints of pinot noir and earthy saison yeast. Very pleasant aroma.  Medium / light crisp body thatÂ’s a bit rough with lightly sharp carbonation.  Starts with much more of the pinot noir barrel aging right off the bat.  All of the aroma traits are there with a earthy/woody abrasiveness that works great for the beer.  The finish is very dry and flowery with lots of barrel notes and a lasting crisp peppercorn flavor sticking to the tongue.  Another great beer from Anchorage.  They are two for two now & canÂ’t wait to see whatÂ’s next.

Bottle shared at The BeerMongers...  Poured golden with a white-ish head.  Pinot wine-like oak and Brett on the nose.  Spices really shined in the initial flavors with the peppercorns being most notable. Some vinous wine-like characters and musky Brett yeast and esters. A little bit of bitter rind and citrus characters too.
